user.name: Lucas Beyer (bl16)
user.description:
Researcher, Head of PR (now: OpenAI, ex: DeepMind, Brain, RWTH Aachen), Gamer, Hacker, Belgian. Anon feedback: https://t.co/xe2XUqkKit
✗DMs → email

entities.text:
SigLIP is an absolute goated vision model 🐐

I use it almost every day for zero-shot text-to-image matching.

For example, having a large folder of images and finding out which ones contain “food” using just the search term “a photo of food”.

How?

SigLIP stands for “Sigmoid Language Image Pretraining”.

In a nutshell, it’s a model that learns a joint representation of vision and language so the two become interchangeable.

The best part is that it’s open-source!

That’s why it’s also the vision backbone of many of the open-source VLMs coming out (Idefics3, PaliGemma, HPT-Edge).

For more on SigLIP and how it was trained, I’d highly recommend watching this talk from

entities.name: Lucas Beyer (bl16)
entities.text: @giffmana

, one of the co-creators of the model (where the slide is from).

(of course read the paper too but I find talks often contain little bits of information you may not pick up on in papers)

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: A screenshot showing a table with image-to-text matching probabilities in a demo titled 'A colab demo with brand-new examples'. The table compares various images, including an iPod, an apple, and a group of people, with corresponding descriptions. The row highlighted in green shows high accuracy (98%) for the match 'a photo of the SigLIP authors'. A presenter is visible in the bottom right corner of the screen, participating in the demo.

user.name: Daniel Bourke
user.description:
• Teaching Beginner-Friendly ML Courses @zerotomasteryio (https://t.co/SGxUchebqe)
• Building ML @nutrifyfoodapp (https://t.co/T8DzQnU4sG)

entities.text:
One of my favourite quotes from the talk was:

“the more precise your text, the higher the score”

This pays big dividends when you’re sorting through a large dataset or doing precise image labelling.

As seen with the goat emojis demo, the more specific the text, the higher the score.

Demo notes: 
- I used Softmax but SigLIP can also use Sigmoid.
- Softmax = all text scores weighted against each other, scaled between 0 & 1 and add to 1 (usually a clear winner).
- Sigmoid = all text scores weighted individually (can be multiple winners).

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: Three images of a goat emoji are shown: Image 1 depicts a plain goat, Image 2 depicts the goat wearing a small top hat, and Image 3 depicts the goat wearing a top hat with small cows as roller skates. Below each image is a probability bar chart with three matching captions. For Image 1, the caption 'an emoji of a goat' has the highest probability (0.981). For Image 2, 'an emoji of a goat with a small top hat' has the highest probability (0.990). For Image 3, 'an emoji of a goat with a small top hat and small cows as roller skates' has the highest probability (0.966).

user.name: Daniel Bourke
user.description:
• Teaching Beginner-Friendly ML Courses @zerotomasteryio (https://t.co/SGxUchebqe)
• Building ML @nutrifyfoodapp (https://t.co/T8DzQnU4sG)

entities.text:
An open-source model like this opens up huge possibilities.

Such as... 

Custom dataset computer vision workflow*:

1. Start with large image dataset (e.g. COYO700M/DataComp-1B or larger if you have resources)
2. Embed images/texts with SigLIP -> index with FAISS (or similar) 
3. Define text ontology for precise extraction
4. Filter samples with zero-shot image/text matching
5. Use samples for downstream specific vision task improvement (e.g. to fine-tune a smaller vision model & deploy this to device, this is what I do at Nutrify)
6. ????
7. Profit
8. Bonus: Use filtered samples with SigLIP + image caption model + image generation model to generate even more task-specific samples

*should work quite well with any vision task you could reasonably expect to exist on the internet (e.g. if your task requires super specific custom vision data, this may not work as well)

entities.text:
What makes CLIP work?
The contrast with negatives via softmax?
The more negatives, the better -> large batch-size?

We'll answer "no" to both in our ICCV oral🤓
By introducing SigLIP, a simpler CLIP that also works better and is more scalable, we can study the extremes.

Hop in🧶

user.name: Lucas Beyer (bl16)
user.description:
Researcher, Head of PR (now: OpenAI, ex: DeepMind, Brain, RWTH Aachen), Gamer, Hacker, Belgian. Anon feedback: https://t.co/xe2XUqkKit
✗DMs → email

entities.text:
Perhaps surprisingly, we can replace the SoftMax-xent by a Sigmoid-xent loss in CLIP training and things just work.

With one little detail: add a learnable bias, much like the temperature.

This is conceptually simpler and cleaner: does image I and text T match: yes or no?

user.name: Lucas Beyer (bl16)
user.description:
Researcher, Head of PR (now: OpenAI, ex: DeepMind, Brain, RWTH Aachen), Gamer, Hacker, Belgian. Anon feedback: https://t.co/xe2XUqkKit
✗DMs → email

entities.text:
It's also much simpler code, and since every element in the similarity matrix is independent, makes it obvious that we can compute the loss "in chunks" across devices.

Chunked sigmoid loss never instantiates the full all-to-all matrix, hence letting us scale batch-size.

user.name: Lucas Beyer (bl16)
user.description:
Researcher, Head of PR (now: OpenAI, ex: DeepMind, Brain, RWTH Aachen), Gamer, Hacker, Belgian. Anon feedback: https://t.co/xe2XUqkKit
✗DMs → email

entities.text:
Surprisingly, we find that both SigLIP and CLIP both plateau at batch-sizes not much larger than 32k, originally used in CLIP.

We also investigate the LiT (
arxiv.org/abs/2111.07991
) setting, where we can reach batch-size of 1 Million. However, we see almost no benefit beyond 32k.

user.name: Lucas Beyer (bl16)
user.description:
Researcher, Head of PR (now: OpenAI, ex: DeepMind, Brain, RWTH Aachen), Gamer, Hacker, Belgian. Anon feedback: https://t.co/xe2XUqkKit
✗DMs → email

entities.text:
Next, we push efficiency to the extreme:

- With SigLiT we get to 80% ImageNet 0shot in just 1 day on 4 devices(!!)

- With SigLIP we get to 73% in 5 days on 32 devices. This is MUCH better than OpenAI (256 for 12 days?) and OpenCLIP (800? for ? days)

entities.text:
🥳 Release of the open-source reproduction of CapPa
🎉 Beats every open-source model on all but one benchmark of SugarCrepe
📕 Apache 2 model weights
👓 Can be used as strong vision model for downstream tasks

👉 Let’s dive in

user.name: Boris Dayma 🖍️
user.description:
🖍️ Founder of Craiyon
🥑 Author of dalle-mini

entities.text:
CapPa is trained as a captioner and masked prediction on large noisy image/text dataset.

It represents an alternative to building vision models through classification (on ImageNet) or contrastive learning (like CLIP).

user.name: Boris Dayma 🖍️
user.description:
🖍️ Founder of Craiyon
🥑 Author of dalle-mini

entities.text:
We mask the full caption 75% of the time 🤯

Intuitively, it helps in preventing the model from guessing the logical end of the caption from its start and rely more on the vision embeddings.

This helps in building a strong vision model for downstream tasks.

user.name: Boris Dayma 🖍️
user.description:
🖍️ Founder of Craiyon
🥑 Author of dalle-mini

entities.text:
The model architecture is mostly similar to a ViT L/16 with a few tweaks.

We also use vision registers to provide a way for the model to encode global information without relying on local patches. Results in nice attention maps!

See "Vision Transformers Need Registers"

user.name: Boris Dayma 🖍️
user.description:
🖍️ Founder of Craiyon
🥑 Author of dalle-mini

entities.text:
We beat every other open source model on SugarCrepe except for the category "Replace Object".

It matches results from the CapPa paper except they get slightly better metrics.

user.name: Boris Dayma 🖍️
user.description:
🖍️ Founder of Craiyon
🥑 Author of dalle-mini

entities.text:
A big advantage of this model is that we have a clearer access to its knowledge.

Few samples:
- good at OCR
- great cultural knowledge
- hallucinate details (non-issue for downstream)
- likely leakage from near-duplicates

Full predictions (non cherry picked) in report

user.name: Boris Dayma 🖍️
user.description:
🖍️ Founder of Craiyon
🥑 Author of dalle-mini

entities.text:
Even without being trained on classification/contrastive, the model is good at zero-shot prediction on ImageNet (63%).

We can further improve it with a quick training as a SigLiT model (frozen vision tower, text tower trained from scratch) to get to 74% top 1 / 93% top 5.

user.name: Boris Dayma 🖍️
user.description:
🖍️ Founder of Craiyon
🥑 Author of dalle-mini

entities.text: The model is mainly meant to be used as a vision tower for downstream tasks but you can play with it in the inference demo:
github.com/borisdayma/cli…
A port to 🤗 Transformers is being worked on.

user.name: Boris Dayma 🖍️

🖍️ Founder of Craiyon

user.name: Xiaohua Zhai
user.description: Senior Staff Research Scientist @GoogleDeepMind team in Zürich

entities.text:
Yes, we know everyone likes small models, so do us!

As recommended by the SoViT paper, we train a SigLIP model using the So400M vision backbone. The So400M model achieves 83.2% 0-shot acc. on ImageNet, outperforming larger released models.

Try it out and enjoy small models!

user.name: Xiaohua Zhai
user.description: Senior Staff Research Scientist @GoogleDeepMind team in Zürich

entities.text:
We care about i18n performance too. That's why we created the i18n WebLI dataset in the first place.

A mSigLIP Base model achieves 42.6% text-to-image 0-shot retrieval recall@1 across 36 langs on XM3600. This is on par with the current SOTA using a Large model.

user.name: Xiaohua Zhai
user.description: Senior Staff Research Scientist @GoogleDeepMind team in Zürich

蚂蚁上树 (ants climbing a tree)

松鼠鳜鱼 (squirrel mandarinfish)

The i18n mSigLIP Base model not only understands languages, but also understands different cultures!

entities.text: The standard cross-entropy that incorporates softmax is a contrastive loss.

user.name: François Fleuret
user.description: Research Scientist @meta (FAIR), Prof. @Unige_en, co-founder @nc_shape. I like reality.

entities.text: Remove "that incorporates softmax" and the question becomes a little more interesting.

user.name: Oriol Vinyals
user.description:
VP of Research & Deep Learning Lead, Google DeepMind. Gemini co-lead.

Past: AlphaStar, AlphaFold, AlphaCode, WaveNet, seq2seq, distillation, TF.

entities.text:
I am not sure what the question becomes then.

The normalization would have to be somewhere, and the loss would degenerate to a readout taking into account a single logit. Not really contrastive.

user.name: François Fleuret
user.description: Research Scientist @meta (FAIR), Prof. @Unige_en, co-founder @nc_shape. I like reality.

entities.text: I think it's wrong to call a loss contrastive, b/c it's the training process itself that is IMHO contrastive and not the loss alone. For vanilla classification task, e.g., sentiment analysis it's surely not contrastive, but with hard negatives and embeddings training it is.

user.name: Leo Boytsov
user.description: Sr. Research Scientist @AWS Labs (ph-D @LTIatCMU) working on (un)natural language processing, speaking πtorch & C++. Opinions sampled from MY OWN 100T param LM.

entities.text:
But cross-entropy is such that a single logit is meaningless in itself, and makes sense only wrt the others.

Seems quite contrastive to me.

user.name: François Fleuret
user.description: Research Scientist @meta (FAIR), Prof. @Unige_en, co-founder @nc_shape. I like reality.

entities.text: yes, contrastive given the normalization term in the softmax

user.name: Guglielmo Camporese
user.description: research engineer at @disney - phd grad at unipd (italy), prev applied scientist at @amazonscience (aws ai labs & alexa ai).

entities.text:
You can see the rows of the weight matrix of the last layer as prototype representations for each class. These prototypes are contrasted against the representations coming from the penultimate layer activations.

Btw.. this is also the reason why normalize the last weight matrix.

user.name: Günter Klambauer
user.description: Deep Learning researcher known for self-normalizing neural networks, applications of Machine Learning in Life Sciences areas; ELLIS program Director

entities.text: Standard cross-entropy with softmax is not a contrastive loss. It focuses on classification, while contrastive loss aims to learn similarity/dissimilarity between pairs of samples. Different objectives, different contexts.

user.name: andretmal
user.description: to-do

entities.text: CE loss is nothing but the KL(data; model) up to a constant. As such, it is contrast between the data density and the model's density under the data distribution.

user.name: Danilo J. Rezende
user.description: Head of AI Research @ EIT | ex-Director @ DeepMind Building models to accelerate fundamental sciences and medicine. Opinions my own.

entities.text:
Obviously, it is contrastive: it pushes down the energy of the correct answer and pushes up the energies of all incorrect answers.
Where energy == -logit
The softmax is seen as part of the loss function, not the network architecture.

user.name: Yann LeCun
user.description:

entities.text:
Let f(x) = sum_i^n f_i(x), where f_i(x) = x_i^2. You can set the step size so that when function 'i' is chosen, you perfectly optimize coordinate 'i'.

Using full batch solves this in one step, with 'n' f_i' evaluations. SGD (batch size 1) takes O(n log n) expected steps.

entities.text: OpenAI first introduced CLIP, a contrastive loss training between image and caption (text) pairs. For a batch size of B, we will have a BxB matrix, where the diagonals are true image-text pairs, and in the contrastive loss, we will increase the probability of diagonal elements.

user.name: Astarag Mogapatra
user.description: AI’ing my way through life. In the job market

entities.text: And decrease the probability of non-diagonal elements. We will compute the softmax for probabilities. The softmax is generally unstable due to the exponential, hence people subtract the maximum value from each element for numerical stability.

user.name: Astarag Mogapatra
user.description: AI’ing my way through life. In the job market

1827565856303542660.location: Softmax loss for language image pre-training

entities.text: But the main issue is with the batch size and memory. We have to compute the normalization term (denominator) for both image and text (once along the row and once along the column). We need to fit the entire BxB matrix in the memory, does not scale well with increasing batch size

user.name: Astarag Mogapatra
user.description: AI’ing my way through life. In the job market

entities.text: Also, the contrastive loss can be hurt if we take all the image and text pairs and compute the loss, as in a batch we may have similar images with similar text. Hence, the main issue is batch size and memory. The sigmoid loss can be useful here

user.name: Astarag Mogapatra
user.description: AI’ing my way through life. In the job market

1827567012446662735.location: Sigmoid loss for language image pre-training

entities.text: In SigLIP, we shift the question from "pick the right class" from this set of images given a text or picking the right text from this set of texts, to rate a pair of images and its text corresponding to another image and text. It is a binary classification with the sigmoid loss.

user.name: Astarag Mogapatra
user.description: AI’ing my way through life. In the job market

entities.text: This solves the memory issue, because to compute the loss, we don't need to load the entire BxB matrix for computing the normalization, we can just compute the loss for a given (image1,text1) and (image1,text2) pair (and the other pair). We can scale the batch size.

user.name: Astarag Mogapatra
user.description: AI’ing my way through life. In the job market

entities.text: In the paper, the authors mentioned that the zero-shot accuracy on ImageNet saturates after 32K batch size for SigLip, and for smaller batch sizes SigLIP performs better than CLIP. But with increasing batch size, the performance converges.

user.name: Astarag Mogapatra
user.description: AI’ing my way through life. In the job market

entities.text: But there is an issue here, for a batch size of BxB, there are only B positive pairs and B^2 - B negative pairs, which is a classic class imbalance problem. To ameliorate that, the authors empirically add a bias term to the loss with an initial value of -10.

user.name: Astarag Mogapatra
user.description: AI’ing my way through life. In the job market

1827570905704493118.location: SigLiT: Scaling batch size to the limit

entities.text:
It makes it robust to over-correction from imbalanced classes. Pseudo-code
Normalize the image encoder (ViT) and text (transformer) encoder outputs --> Build a BxB matrix with a diagonal being 1 and non-diagonal -1 --> Compute the dot product between image and text embeddings.

user.name: Astarag Mogapatra
user.description: AI’ing my way through life. In the job market

1827571802157281361.location: SigLIP: Sigmoid loss is beneficial for languageimage pre-training

entities.text: Finally, compute the sigmoid loss.

user.name: Boris Dayma 🖍️
user.description:
🖍️ Founder of Craiyon
🥑 Author of dalle-mini

entities.text:
I got about 20-30% speed gain based on the model by upgrading to latest JAX/Flax API's and leveraging JAX arrays.

I've also been playing a lot with the profiler to ensure optimal sharding of operations. Sometimes minor rewrite to equivalent ops help the compiler with sharding

user.name: Boris Dayma 🖍️
user.description:
🖍️ Founder of Craiyon
🥑 Author of dalle-mini

entities.text: You basically calculate the loss on each device with its local data, and then iteratively swap data between devices to compute loss between negative examples and add it to your local loss.

user.name: Boris Dayma 🖍️
user.description:
🖍️ Founder of Craiyon
🥑 Author of dalle-mini

entities.text:
This concept is very easy to implement in JAX with `shard_map`:
* it defines a function that happen on a single TPU
* loss initialized to local sigmoid between +/- samples
* iterate permuting image samples between TPU's, keeping text samples the same and adding negative loss

user.name: Boris Dayma 🖍️
user.description:
🖍️ Founder of Craiyon
🥑 Author of dalle-mini

entities.text:
Overall this was a nice toy to play with `shard_map`.

It is especially interesting when you want to optimize your computation, whether for speed or memory, providing an easy way to define local input/output sharding and how it is performed.

user.name: Boris Dayma 🖍️
user.description:
🖍️ Founder of Craiyon
🥑 Author of dalle-mini

entities.text: I did some mini-tests and everything seemed fine (thanks

entities.name: Lucas Beyer (bl16)
entities.text: @giffmana

for paper clarifications).
On few devices, chunked loss is a bit faster than cross-entropy.
On many devices, you can fit a larger batch than you would have been able to.

“Do Anything Now”: Characterizing and Evaluating In-The-Wild Jailbreak Prompts on Large Language Models
arxiv.org/abs/2308.03825

Platypus: Quick, Cheap, and Powerful Refinement of LLMs
arxiv.org/abs/2308.07317
The 13B Platypus model can be trained on a single A100 GPU in 5 hours with 25k questions, offering strong performance with significantly less data and compute resources than other SOTA LLMs
TeCH: Text-guided Reconstruction of Lifelike Clothed Humans
arxiv.org/abs/2308.08545
TeCH has introduced a new method for reconstructing 3D clothed human figures from a single image, addressing the unsolved challenge of accurately restoring "unseen regions" of the body.
XSTest: A Test Suite for Identifying Exaggerated Safety Behaviours in Large Language Models
arxiv.org/abs/2308.01263
Using XSTEST, the paper found that the Llama2 exhibits exaggerated safety behavior, refusing 38% of test prompts and partially refusing another 22%.

Awesome work! However..
A bit confused here. Why are you saying that the batch size is not part of the recipe for why CLIP works, and then show a figure that clearly shows that batch size does matter up to 32K, after which it plateaus? Same for the contrast stuff, sigmoid and softmax while different, both try to optimize for similar things, hence, there is still contrast being captured, but more so in a less coupled way, hence allowing for more flexibility. The latter is something used in segmentation literature often for example, and is known as a better alternative to softmax, among others that prove even more powerful (such as dice loss and focal loss).

entities.text: This is huge. Pairwise loss for distance learning was often inferior to contrastive loss or triplet loss because the later consider relative distances between points at a given neighborhood. However, they dont scale well to large batch size.

entities.name: Lucas Beyer (bl16)
entities.text: @giffmana

and colleagues introduced SigLIP, an efficient pairwise loss that unlocks (very) large scale distance learning.
But I am sure it's not over yet!!! Who's gonna discover the next big trick???

entities.text:
[1/n] a brief thread on why "maxing the batchsize can hurt performance". 

Tuning the batchsize has a non-monotonic effect on runtime. 

Larger batchsize => faster passes over data (because of GPU util+lower comm. cost)
BUT  bsize affects iterations to ε acc in a weird way.

entities.text: Not surprised.  Always thought Softmax is iffy.  Whether a class exist in an image (other things) should be independent measured instead of relative to possibilities of other classes.

In short, there is a discrepancy between what log-likelihood loss for detection is optimising and what is good for mAP (or for whatever a user wants). Luckily, an additional lightweight Reinforcement Learning tuning can be used to align the model with the end goal.

At only 5B parameters, it's also smaller (and stronger) than the concurrent Fuyu-8B model, though sadly we cannot release the model (props to

user.name: Lucas Beyer (bl16)
user.description:
Researcher, Head of PR (now: OpenAI, ex: DeepMind, Brain, RWTH Aachen), Gamer, Hacker, Belgian. Anon feedback: https://t.co/xe2XUqkKit
✗DMs → email

entities.text:
PaLI consist of [1] a pre-trained image encoder (ViT) turning images to tokens, [2] a pre-trained encoder-decoder LLM (UL2).
They are combined by concatenating input tokens and training the joint model on an image-text mixture.

For the first time, we revisit pre-training of [1].

user.name: Lucas Beyer (bl16)
user.description:
Researcher, Head of PR (now: OpenAI, ex: DeepMind, Brain, RWTH Aachen), Gamer, Hacker, Belgian. Anon feedback: https://t.co/xe2XUqkKit
✗DMs → email

entities.text:
Previously, we pretrain using classification on JFT (eg ViT-22B). Here, we *directly compare* that vs SigLIP pretraining.

linear probing, a common indicator of model quality, makes SigLIP look worse. But plugged into PaLI, SigLIP far outperforms, especially on complex tasks.

user.name: Lucas Beyer (bl16)
user.description:
Researcher, Head of PR (now: OpenAI, ex: DeepMind, Brain, RWTH Aachen), Gamer, Hacker, Belgian. Anon feedback: https://t.co/xe2XUqkKit
✗DMs → email

entities.text: On text/document/infographics types of tasks, PaLI-3 shines even without any separate OCR input (that's a common thing there). This gain comes partially from the SigLIP pre-training and partially form an improved data mix.

user.name: Lucas Beyer (bl16)
user.description:
Researcher, Head of PR (now: OpenAI, ex: DeepMind, Brain, RWTH Aachen), Gamer, Hacker, Belgian. Anon feedback: https://t.co/xe2XUqkKit
✗DMs → email

entities.text: One other cool thing is that PaLI-3 is SOTA, or competitive with SOTA on a whole range of video tasks, even though it's not pre-trained on video tasks (only the final fine-tuning is), by just concatenating tokens from a few frames.

If you still care about ImageNet, we also do the standard ImageNet things with the 2B SigLIP encoder, and it matches or outperforms the larger JFT-based ones, including 22B. Except on v2, and again not in linear probes.

It's actually mSigLIP (multilingual) → great on X3600 too!

user.name: Dimitris Papailiopoulos
user.description: Researcher @MSFTResearch; Prof @UWMadison (on leave); learning in context; thinking about reasoning; babas of Inez Lily.

entities.text:
2/n (old but still relevant slides)
Large bsize is good for system reasons:
=> speedup over 1 worker/thread/GPU becomes more and more aligned with linear, as bsize increases

should be relatively obvious why

user.name: Dimitris Papailiopoulos
user.description: Researcher @MSFTResearch; Prof @UWMadison (on leave); learning in context; thinking about reasoning; babas of Inez Lily.

entities.text:
3/n but increasing bsize has a non-monotonic effect on convergence, i..e, num of iterations to a given accuracy

Note: this is an old figure (tensorflow, boo gen Z), but the phenomenon was/is pretty universal across most supervised classification settings we tried.

WHY?

user.name: Dimitris Papailiopoulos
user.description: Researcher @MSFTResearch; Prof @UWMadison (on leave); learning in context; thinking about reasoning; babas of Inez Lily.

entities.text:
4/n 
High-level mental framework on why this happens:

Redundant grads => slower convergence

Increasing the bsize (beyond a point) makes individual gradients too similar to each other. 

Extreme case: with insanely large bsize you'll resample the same data points => useless

user.name: Dimitris Papailiopoulos
user.description: Researcher @MSFTResearch; Prof @UWMadison (on leave); learning in context; thinking about reasoning; babas of Inez Lily.

entities.text:
5/n There's a very clean (i think) optimization viewpoint that supports the hypothesis  
"increasing bsize => increases grad redundancy => hurts convergence rates"

The key is to understand this is to compare a single step of SGD vs single step of minibatch SGD (in the slides B = bsize)

user.name: Dimitris Papailiopoulos
user.description: Researcher @MSFTResearch; Prof @UWMadison (on leave); learning in context; thinking about reasoning; babas of Inez Lily.

entities.text:
6/n Let's see what happens during 1 iteration of SGD and calibrate our expectations for minibatch SGD.

High level idea, 1-sample SGD makes some progress towards a desired direction. 

This is captured by a (-) term that takes you closer to there and a (+) that pushes away

user.name: Dimitris Papailiopoulos
user.description: Researcher @MSFTResearch; Prof @UWMadison (on leave); learning in context; thinking about reasoning; babas of Inez Lily.

entities.text:
7/n minibatch SGD does the same but the - and + terms look a bit different 

We have bsize times larger (-) term (nice) and a variance like + term we need to quantify

user.name: Dimitris Papailiopoulos
user.description: Researcher @MSFTResearch; Prof @UWMadison (on leave); learning in context; thinking about reasoning; babas of Inez Lily.

entities.text:
8/n If you compare the "progress" that 1 vs B sample SGD make this is what you get: 

The good stuff (-) for minibatch is a factor of B better and 
the bad stuff (+) is directly controlled by B, so we could set it so that B sample SGD is B times "faster" than 1-sample SGD

user.name: Dimitris Papailiopoulos
user.description: Researcher @MSFTResearch; Prof @UWMadison (on leave); learning in context; thinking about reasoning; babas of Inez Lily.

entities.text: 9/n if you do this, the "magic" bsize looks like this

user.name: Dimitris Papailiopoulos
user.description: Researcher @MSFTResearch; Prof @UWMadison (on leave); learning in context; thinking about reasoning; babas of Inez Lily.

entities.text:
10/n The magic bsize has to be proportional to something that we call "gradient diversity" capturing how dissimilar grads in a batch are.
max = orthogonal grads, min = colinear grads

Point being:
If the bsize is ~ grad diversity, minibatch SGD is like bsize iterations of SGD

user.name: Dimitris Papailiopoulos
user.description: Researcher @MSFTResearch; Prof @UWMadison (on leave); learning in context; thinking about reasoning; babas of Inez Lily.

entities.text: 11/12 in the 2017 paper
arxiv.org/abs/1706.05699
we use this idea to recover a bunch of convergence rates to say, if you set your bsize ~ grad diversity there are no diminishing returns

user.name: Dimitris Papailiopoulos
user.description: Researcher @MSFTResearch; Prof @UWMadison (on leave); learning in context; thinking about reasoning; babas of Inez Lily.

entities.text:
12/12 and in experiments we do ablate for diversity by replicating chunks of the train data. This was to show how it directly controls how the extra time one needs to spend to reach similar acc on large vs small bsize runs

(yeah we used TF back in the day, BOO)

user.name: Dimitris Papailiopoulos
user.description: Researcher @MSFTResearch; Prof @UWMadison (on leave); learning in context; thinking about reasoning; babas of Inez Lily.

entities.text:
12+1/12 
Remark: there're many ways to argue for how bsize affects SGD, and many great folks have posed meaningful hypotheses.

entities.text: Great suggestion, it’s also among top 40 papers this year

Breakdown of the paper:

The study presents the development of a new set of foundation models called Llama 3, which is a herd of language models that can handle multiple languages, coding, reasoning, and tool usage. The flagship model has 405 billion parameters and can process up to 128,000 tokens at a time.

The evaluation results show that Llama 3 performs comparably to leading language models like GPT-4 on a variety of tasks, including commonsense reasoning, knowledge, reading comprehension, math and reasoning, and coding. The smaller Llama 3 models (8B and 70B) outperform models of similar sizes, while the flagship 405B model is competitive with the state-of-the-art.

entities.text:
If you are open to hacking a solution:

1. Use phi 3.5 vision to scan through all the images (should be fast, is a light model). Use this to generate image descriptions.

2. Extract metadata from the image and store that with the descriptions 

3. Write a search that searches these descriptions associated with images. Potentially using some vector similarity type search.

You won't get the "recognize face" feature using this method do, but it's fast, easy and private.

1.title: Softmax loss for language image pre-training

4.title: SigLIP: Sigmoid loss is beneficial for languageimage pre-training

2.title: Sigmoid loss for language image pre-training

3.title: SigLiT: Scaling batch size to the limit

Introduction.Resource:
<1828164161643098116> suggested using SigLIP for freeform image search, highlighting its applicability to the user's goal.
<1828107019062284719> mentioned using PaliGemma for automated labeling and indexing, offering an alternative approach.
Introduction.Perspective: <1823684914476409326> praises SigLIP's performance in auto-labeling, highlighting its ability to recognize both text and image features.

null.Q&A:
<1824076631889084550> questioned the model's struggle to detect "lion head," prompting <1824190045819130321> to explain that the example tested cultural diversity, with "lion head" in English scoring well with lion images, while the Chinese equivalent ranked highest with a traditional dish.

<1824201391084360040> further probed the model's interesting behavior with "cow" images, noting perfect classification of beach and tuxedo cows but lower scores for "cow" alone, possibly due to tokenization.

<1692729153064194467> inquired about embedding comparisons with CLIP, particularly for the text encoder, to which <1692803516778119440> asked for suggestions on comparison methods.

<1692961520769007696> questioned the calculation of top-1 accuracy for image-to-text retrieval with multiple captions, and <1693003046790242595> clarified that any matching caption being top-1 counts as a correct retrieval.

<1692926798365954215> pointed out the similarity of a technique in the paper to one used in word2vec, and <1693007656007467413> acknowledged the potential connection and promised to investigate.

Other discussions included questions about performance plateaus at 32k, the need for data augmentations, the impact of batch construction, and the intuition behind SigLIP's outperformance of softmax.  There was also a question about encoding entire words without tokenization.
null.Resource: <1858429282474684532> shared a multilingual version of SigLIP, available at [[huggingface.co/google/siglip-…]], extending the paper's applicability.
null.Critique:
<1708404728990765178> highlighted the significant impact of dataset choice (WebLI, Laion2B, WIT) on zero-shot accuracies, referencing a related paper.

<1708611235611066791> clarified that experiments used a consistent setup to avoid confounders, except for the "SOTA table" which reflects off-the-shelf model performance.

<1693084749219147880> suggested verifying the explanation's plausibility by calculating statistics on near-duplicates in the dataset.
null.Perspective:
<1721370796814180774> reported a 10% performance increase using SigLIP with a smaller visual encoder, praising the model and loss function.
<1869576274722816364> recommended the SigLIP paper as an introductory resource due to its comprehensive content and numerous references.

Caption 1.Q&A:
<1827567724475629933> inquired about the impact of smaller batch sizes on gradient stability in CLIP training with sigmoid loss.
<1827569673287954630> responded by referencing the paper's findings that sigmoid loss performs better with smaller batch sizes but converges as batch size increases, although gradient stability wasn't directly addressed.
<1827570199098487067> offered an intuition that sigmoid loss's simpler task of differentiating image-text pairs might explain its better performance with smaller batch sizes.

<1692961052542353724> questioned the reason behind SigLIP's poorer performance with larger batch sizes.

Other discussions are not present in the provided conversation data.
Caption 1.Critique:
<1692730202604896657> challenges the paper's assertion about batch size, citing experimental results showing its impact up to 32K.


Other discussions not included here did not meet the criteria for intellectual depth and insightfulness.

Related Work.Resource:
<1707328464645234738> announced the release of SigLIP models and shared a Colab notebook for experimentation [[colab.research.google.com/github/google-…]].
        
<1797636065995706601> explained that PaliGemma uses SigLIP and linked to the SigLIP paper [[arxiv.org/pdf/2303.15343]] and a related Hugging Face space [[huggingface.co/spaces/merve/c…]].
        
<1797636068533219347> provided a Colab notebook for fine-tuning PaliGemma [[colab.research.google.com/github/roboflo…]].
        
Other posts mention additional resources and tutorials related to PaliGemma and its application to object detection.
Related Work.Related Work:
<1692813024363512135> CLAMP (ICML2023) [[arxiv.org/abs/2303.03363]] also utilizes the sigmoid loss function.
<1693120666898481328> Szegedy's 2019 work [[arxiv.org/abs/1905.10006]] uses the same loss and explores semi-hard negative mining.

Method.Q&A:
<1692674120310296765> questioned the training time delta, attributing it to the loss term computation over every pair. <1692801455114031398> clarified that the efficiency comes from never materializing the matrix.
<1692825105846735311> asked if the loss assumes all other pairs in the batch are negative examples. <1693005123725742421> confirmed this, acknowledging it's a reasonable but potentially limiting assumption for large datasets.
<1692733765963944155> wondered about the competitiveness of BYOL losses. <1692812263248245017> expressed curiosity about applying BYOL and SimCLR in this context.
<1692645165511430165> inquired about tricks like hard negative mining. <1692647428770484279> pointed to the importance of the learnable bias and its initialization.
<1696708871342141668> questioned the normalization factor of 1/B instead of 1/B^2.

Other discussions touched on the theoretical underpinnings of the loss function and its connection to mutual information, as well as the increasing batch sizes in modern neural network training.
Method.Resource:
<1703163140224237801> discusses the implementation of SigLIP in PyTorch, highlighting the challenge of replicating the `jax.lax.ppermute` functionality.
<1703174443072098547> points out SigLIP's advantage over CLIP in terms of resource efficiency, especially for academic GPU servers.
<1706048868360560649> inquires about the possibility of integrating SigLIP with OpenCLIP via Timm.
<1706055157325406468> confirms the potential integration with OpenCLIP and mentions its application in a document AI project.
<1703222268342743481> expresses interest in applying SigLIP to large satellite imagery datasets.

Other noteworthy points include the open-sourcing of the JAX code by <1703308904749322285>.
Method.Perspective:
<1640820996696576002> expressed surprise at the effectiveness of using sigmoid loss for image-text pre-training.

<1640831736228597762> suggested that softmax may not be ideal as class existence in an image should be measured independently, not relative to other classes.

Efficient \"chunked\" implementation.Q&A:
<1693301205886480733> inquired about the influence of per-core batch size on the overall performance when scaling the total batch size across different numbers of cores.

Other discussions touched upon the efficiency of sigmoid loss for large-batch training.

Conclusion.Q&A:
<1692934265087152626> questioned whether the sigmoid loss technique could be applied to fixed vocabularies used in LMs.

<1693009418974056590> suggested it might work, referencing prior success with ImageNet classification using a similar approach.

Results.Q&A:
<1692678733042249873> inquired about the missing metric for text-to-image retrieval results in the paper.

<1692801825622065212> clarified that the metric used was Top-1 (later corrected to R@1).

<1693333547149668574> questioned the seemingly lower performance compared to the prior LiT paper, given similar model configurations, and expressed confusion about the low OpenCLIP scores.

Other discussions touched on the difficulty of improving performance on large-scale datasets like Flickr30k and STAIR, even with R@10.

Abstract.Perspective:
<1803951586693325157> reported successful application of a SigCLR-inspired approach with SigLIP for aerial imagery, achieving good retrieval results.

<1704151772095226082> shared their implementation of SigLIP for fMRI to natural scene image retrieval, noting ongoing work to improve performance compared to a soft clip loss.

Other discussions are not relevant.
Abstract.Resource: <1694066373175943672> pointed out that the paper uses the BigVision library [[github.com/google-research/big_vision]], which also clarifies the weight decay application, a detail relevant to reproducing the results.

Caption 2.Q&A: <1695131625187573908> inquired about the missing Hebrew language code ("he") in Table 2, asking which code was used instead.

Lij.Q&A: <1693283249001230679> questions if initializing the bias term (b) as half the temperature (t), with t=-20, would yield similar results as the paper's initialization.

Stabilizing large-batch training.Q&A:
<1835750607782838683> inquired about the source of a recommendation to set beta_2=0.95 in the Adam optimizer.
<1835764432347005032> pointed to the SigLIP paper as the source of this recommendation.
<1835764718343946345> expressed gratitude for the information.
